nodes.bodyText: Since the second lexer pushes to the token stream before the TEXT_BLOCK_BEGIN token is returned from the main lexer, we are using the exclude operator to initially not link the AST for TEXT_BLOCK_CONTENT to the textBlock rule so that we can construct the correct form of the AST in the action on line 1737.

nodes.bodyText: I am getting complaints from both IDEA and TeamCity about this:  JUnit test method testImpossibleExceptionsJava14TextBlockLexer() contains no assertions which I understand, but why don't the existing tests (see here) cause this warning?

This means either there is a suppression in the config, or somewhere it is specified that AssertGeneratedJavaLexer.verifyFail is an assertion method.
A quick search finds these rules:
https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/config/pmd-test.xml#L182
https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/config/intellij-idea-inspections.xml#L4618
(the list may be incomplete)

I would like to know a better way to reuse the existing code (see here) .  Should I make AssertGeneratedJavaLexer.java not final, then extend it, or should I refactor AssertGeneratedJavaLexer.java to work with the new lexer, too?
This class is final simply because there was no reason not to make it final before. If you need to re-factor this to support the grammar for text blocks, then go ahead.
After re-examining this, since each class must be a descendant of it's respective lexer, and an interface for these seems like overkill, I am going to leave this as it is.
@pbludov I have added this line, which suppresses the warning locally, but TeamCity is still failing.  Any ideas?

nodes.bodyText:
I would rather do no coverage for such hard to catch code and and bump percentage in config.
we keep percentage in coverage for generated code only to see diff of coverage on new grammar update and probably discuss what could be covered by real inputs.
We do not need to have test on generated code of ANTLR, it is by definition the most trusty code in our code base.
in addition  we always work on javac compiled sources, so we do not care how code works on incomplete/non-compilable java code

ok, looks like @rnveach  was a person who introduced such asserts - 5123ab3 .
ok, lets keep it.
please move this update in separate issue, as we will need test is separately, Check tests need to be updated.

I'm not sure that I follow. If a newline is printed as \n Both the text block characters and escape sequences are being printed exactly how the content is written in the java file, except for one exception; the actual line terminators ( \n in this case) are being added to the "end" of each line. it seems to me \ should be printed as \\ I don't understand why we should add an additional \, can you explain? nodes.bodyText:
Sorry for the confusion, my point was content in the AST.
We escaped special characters. \n, \r, etc.. I would expect everything to follow this escaping even single \ as it will make parsing by others easier.
If someone put in String s = """\\"""; I would expect the AST to to say TEXT_BLOCK_CONTENT -> \\.
This would make it universally clear that all \s are escape characters for the first instance seen.
Imagine if someone put in String s = """\\n""";. As you have your AST generating now, it would say TEXT_BLOCK_CONTENT -> \n. How would we parse this then? By your other rules this would mean the string is purely a new line, and wouldn't be parsed as actual text characters \ and n.
We should escape all \ text seen in the contents.

Imagine if someone put in String s = """\\n""";
